title: Fetch & Process Results
text: primary function retrieving data formr_results().

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: default, formr_results fetches surveys currently use shuffle units ever associated run. run contains multiple surveys (e.g., “Baseline” “Diary”), function returns named list tibbles, one survey.
code: # Fetch all data for a run raw_data <- formr_results("my-study-name")

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: analysis scenarios, want single “wide” dataset one row represents one session. Setting join = TRUE handles automatically. happens join? Merging: Surveys full-joined session identifier. Conflict Resolution: variable names collide (e.g., surveys variable named created), suffixed survey name (e.g., created_baseline, created_diary). Shuffles: run uses randomization (Shuffles), group assignments automatically pivoted wide. example, user assigned “Group ” unit 10, get column shuffle_10 value “Group ”.
code: # Fetch and merge everything by session ID joined_data <- formr_results("my-study-name", join = TRUE)

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: study large-scale, involving thousands participants, variables, repetitions, may want retrieve data need save bandwidth memory. also preferred way get just items interest accessing results within form run.
code: # Fetch only specific surveys results <- formr_results("my-study-name", surveys = c("survey_1", "survey_2"))  # Fetch specific items (columns) results <- formr_results("my-study-name", item_names = c("age", "gender", "extraversion_1"))

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: Statistical analysis raw data server often requires processing. formr_post_process_results() function transforms raw data analysis-ready format using study’s metadata. single function wrapper performs four major steps: Fetches Metadata: downloads survey properties (item types, choice lists) know process data. Type Recognition: Converts strings Dates, choice-based numbers Factors correct labels. Reverse Coding: Automatically reverses items ending R. Aggregation: Automatically computes mean scores scale items.

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: prefer manual control, can run steps individually.

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: Uses item metadata assign classes. Choice items: Converted haven_labelled factors. Labels (e.g., “Strongly Agree”) attached values (e.g., 5). Dates: Converted POSIXct.
code: # Manual Type Recognition items_nested <- formr_run_structure("my-study-name") # Get metadata items_flat <- formr:::.extract_items_from_run(items_nested) raw <- formr_results("my-study-name", join = TRUE) # Get data  step1_data <- formr_recognise(item_list = items_flat, results = raw)

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: Looks items ending R (e.g., neuroticism_3R). determines minimum maximum possible values survey metadata (“choices” list) applies formula: New=(Max+Min)−Old\text{New} = (\text{Max} + \text{Min}) - \text{Old} Note: Attributes added column (e.g., reversal_const) can verify transformation.
code: # Manual Reverse Coding step2_data <- formr_reverse(results = step1_data, item_list = items_flat)

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: Calculates mean scores items sharing common “stem”. example, extra_1, extra_2, extra_3R, function detects stem extra, calculates row-mean, creates new column extra.
code: # Manual Aggregation step3_data <- formr_aggregate(results = step2_data, item_list = items_flat)

title: Fetch & Process Results
text: default, formr_post_process_results() removes test sessions (sessions containing “XXX” code). can keep debugging:
code: # Keep test users debug_data <- formr_post_process_results("my-study-name", remove_test_sessions = FALSE)

title: Getting Started
text: use API features (fetching results, managing files), must first authenticate. can store credentials securely system’s keyring don’t type every time. Log formr.org go Account > API Settings. Create Client ID Secret.
code: library(formr)  # Store your credentials once # This saves them securely in your OS credential store formr_store_keys(   host = "https://formr.org", # or the URL of your instance   client_id = "YOUR_CLIENT_ID",    client_secret = "YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET" )  # Then, in all of your scripts, simply run: formr_api_authenticate(host = "https://formr.org")  # or the URL of your instance

what: You can use the API within your runs R-Code.
title: Getting Started
Getting Started
text: authenticated, can run API functions:

title: Getting Started
text: formr_api_authenticate() provides TOKEN valid Hour. Currently, need rerun authentication . end analysis: Server: running Code formr server, TOKEN gets invalidated automatically. Local Device: running Code local device, may let TOKEN run validity period revoke manually.

title: Manage your Files
text: see files currently attached run, use formr_files(). returns data frame containing file names, public URLs, upload timestamps. returned url column particularly useful need embed assets external emails websites.
code: # List all files attached to the study files <- formr_files("my-study-name")  # View the first few files head(files)

title: Manage your Files
text: can upload files individually bulk. useful quickly patching missing image adding new stimulus without re-syncing entire project.

title: Manage your Files
code: # Upload a single logo formr_upload_file("my-study-name", path = "assets/logo.png")

title: Manage your Files
text: function flexible: can pass vector paths directory. pass directory, formr upload files directly inside .
code: # Upload multiple specific files formr_upload_file("my-study-name", path = c("assets/img1.jpg", "assets/img2.jpg"))  # Upload an entire folder of stimuli formr_upload_file("my-study-name", path = "assets/stimuli/")

title: Manage your Files
text: keep run clean, can remove obsolete files.
code: # Delete a specific file formr_delete_file("my-study-name", file_name = "old_logo.png")  # Delete a list of files formr_delete_file("my-study-name", file_name = c("test1.jpg", "test2.jpg"))

title: Manage your Files
text: restructuring study want start fresh, can wipe files. Use caution.
code: # Delete ALL files (prompts for confirmation) formr_delete_all_files("my-study-name")

title: Manage your Runs
text: see overview studies access , use formr_runs(). returns tidy data frame containing run ID, name, status flags (whether public, locked, active cron jobs).
code: # List all runs and their status runs <- formr_runs()  # Quickly check which runs are currently active/public subset(runs, public == TRUE)

title: Manage your Runs
text: can create new, empty run directly R. useful setting battery studies programmatically. function returns public link new run upon success.
code: # Create a new run named "pilot-study-v1" formr_create_run("pilot-study-v1")

title: Manage your Runs
text: run exists, often need toggle settings—example, locking prevent accidental edits data collection making public participants. formr_run_settings() function handles . GET: provide run name, returns current settings. PATCH: provide settings list, updates run.
code: # 1. View current settings settings <- formr_run_settings("pilot-study-v1")  # 2. Update settings: Lock the run and make it public formr_run_settings("pilot-study-v1", settings = list(   locked = TRUE,     # Prevent structure changes   public = 2,      # Allow participants to access via Link   expiresOn = "2026-12-31"    # Set Data Expiration Date (required to make your Run public) ))

title: Manage your Runs
text: “Structure” run ordered list units (surveys, emails, pauses, jumps) determines participant’s path. can export structure JSON safekeeping import replicate study design.

title: Manage your Runs
text: can inspect structure R list save directly JSON file create 1:1 backup runs configuration.
code: # Inspect structure in R struct <- formr_run_structure("pilot-study-v1") print(struct)  # Save to file (Backup) formr_run_structure("pilot-study-v1", file = "pilot_v1_structure.json")

title: Manage your Runs
text: can upload JSON file replace current run structure. useful creating templates: can define complex flow apply multiple runs. part JSON file, also create necessary surveys run.
code: # Overwrite the run's structure with a local JSON file formr_run_structure("pilot-study-v1", structure_json_path = "pilot_v1_structure.json")

title: Manage your Runs
text: can permanently delete run created mistake longer needed. Warning: remove everything associated run, including structure, attached files, collected results. However, surveys used run kept.
code: # Delete a run (prompts for confirmation by default) formr_delete_run("pilot-study-v1")  # Force delete without confirmation (for automated scripts) formr_delete_run("pilot-study-v1", prompt = FALSE)

title: Manage your Sessions
text: get overview currently study, use formr_sessions(). function returns tidy data frame containing session codes, current position run, timestamps.

title: Manage your Sessions
text: can filter sessions see currently active marked test sessions.
code: # List all active sessions (participants currently in the study) active_users <- formr_sessions("my-run-name", active = TRUE)  # List all test sessions (e.g., generated by you) test_users <- formr_sessions("my-run-name", testing = TRUE)

title: Manage your Sessions
text: know participant’s session code (e.g., user report), can fetch details directly see exactly .
code: # Inspect a specific user user_status <- formr_sessions("my-run-name", session_codes = "USER_CODE_123") dplyr::glimpse(user_status)

title: Manage your Sessions
text: users typically create sessions clicking link, might need generate sessions programmatically. common : Laboratory Studies: Pre-generating codes hand participants. Automated Testing: Creating dummy users test study flow.
code: # Create a random session code for testing new_sessions <- formr_create_session("my-run-name", testing = TRUE)  # Create a session with a specific code (e.g., for a specific ID) # Please be sure that your session codes are in an allowed format on your server. formr_create_session("my-run-name", codes = c("LAB_001", "LAB_002"))

title: Manage your Sessions
text: Sometimes need intervene participant’s progress. formr_session_action() function allows modify state one sessions.

what: Use Case 1: Unstucking a User (Move Position)
title: Manage your Sessions
text: bug logic error causes user get stuck specific point, can manually move different unit run.
code: # Move user to position 10 (e.g., the next survey) formr_session_action("my-run-name",                       session_codes = "STUCK_USER_CODE",                       action = "move_to_position",                       position = 10)

title: Manage your Sessions
text: accidentally performed self-test “real” session code, real participant used test code, can toggle testing flag. helps keep data clean/separate.
code: # Mark a real session as a test session formr_session_action("my-run-name",                       session_codes = "REAL_USER_CODE",                       action = "toggle_testing")

title: Manage your Sessions
text: want manually finish external module session, can “end_external” action.
code: # End a session formr_session_action("my-run-name",                       session_codes = "WITHDRAWN_USER_Code",                       action = "end_external")

title: Manage your Studies
text: Ensure stored API credentials described Getting Started guide.

title: Manage your Studies
text: making major changes, good practice create full backup run. function downloads run structure (JSON), survey item tables (Excel), attached files (images/scripts), current results. creates self-contained archive study state moment.
code: # Download everything to a folder named "backup_my_study" formr_backup_run("my-study-name", dir = "backup_my_study")

title: Manage your Studies
text: recommended workflow active development Pull -> Edit -> Push.

title: Manage your Studies
text: First, create local directory project pull current state server. scaffolds necessary folder structure. create following structure: surveys/: Contains survey spreadsheets (.xlsx). files/: Contains images assets. css/ & js/: Contains custom styling scripts. run_settings.json: Configuration like privacy settings data expiration. run_structure.json: flow run (surveys, pauses, emails).
code: # Pull the project into a local folder formr_pull_project("my-study-name", dir = "my_project_folder")

title: Manage your Studies
text: can now edit files using favorite tools: Open .xlsx files Excel/LibreOffice. Edit .css .js VS Code RStudio. Add new images files/ folder.

title: Manage your Studies
text: happy local changes, push back server. function compares file modification times uploads changed.
code: # Sync local changes to the server formr_push_project("my-study-name", dir = "my_project_folder")

title: Manage your Studies
text: heavily editing survey, running formr_push_project manually every time can tedious. can use watch argument keep connection open. package monitor folder upload changes immediately save files.
code: # Automatically push changes when files are saved (Press Esc to stop) formr_push_project("my-study-name", dir = "my_project_folder", watch = TRUE)

title: Manage your Studies
text: can also view update run settings programmatically. useful toggling specific flags like public locked without navigating UI.
code: # View current settings settings <- formr_run_settings("my-study-name") print(settings)  # Update specific settings formr_run_settings("my-study-name", settings = list(   public = 2,        # Make run accessible via Link   locked = 1        # Lock run   # ... ))

title: Manage your Studies
text: advanced users, entire flow run (“Unit” list) can exported imported JSON. allows template complex study designs import directly.
code: # Export structure to a file formr_run_structure("my-study-name", file = "structure.json")  # Import structure from a file (Replaces current structure!) formr_run_structure("my-study-name", structure_json_path = "structure.json")

title: Manage your Surveys
text: view list surveys associated account, use formr_surveys(). returns tidy data frame containing survey ID, name, modification timestamps. can also filter list name using name_pattern argument.
code: # List all surveys all_surveys <- formr_surveys()  # Find specific surveys (e.g., all diaries) diaries <- formr_surveys(name_pattern = "diary") print(diaries)

title: Manage your Surveys
text: can retrieve content survey two ways: data frame (tibble) inspection R, downloadable Excel file (XLSX).

title: Manage your Surveys
text: useful quickly checking variable names, item types, choice labels without leaving R session.
code: # Get the survey items as a tibble items <- formr_survey_structure("daily_diary_v1")  # Check the first few items head(items)

title: Manage your Surveys
text: lost local copy survey want backup version currently server, can download directly.
code: # Download the survey as an Excel file formr_survey_structure(   survey_name = "daily_diary_v1",    format = "xlsx",    file_path = "backup_daily_diary.xlsx" )

title: Manage your Surveys
text: can upload single survey file directly. useful want update just one component study without syncing entire project folder.
code: # Upload a local Excel file formr_upload_survey(   file_path = "surveys/my_new_survey.xlsx",    survey_name = "my_new_survey" # Optional: Defaults to filename if omitted )

title: Manage your Surveys
text: can also import survey directly published Google Sheet URL.

title: Manage your Surveys
text: can permanently delete survey longer needed.
code: # Delete a survey (prompts for confirmation by default) formr_delete_survey("old_pilot_survey")  # Force delete without confirmation (for automated scripts) formr_delete_survey("old_pilot_survey", prompt = FALSE)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ruben Arslan. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Arslan R (2026). formr: formr survey framework accompanying R package. R package version 0.12.0, http://rubenarslan.github.io/formr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {formr: formr survey framework accompanying R package},   author = {Ruben Arslan},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.12.0},   url = {http://rubenarslan.github.io/formr/}, }

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: formr R package official companion formr survey framework. former package designed provide useful helper functions inside formr surveys (feedback plots logic). Version 0.12.0 introduces robust API client. Now, can use R manage studies locally, sync files, control version surveys, securely fetch results.

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: highly encourage work full documentation tutorials. available rubenarslan.github.io/formr.

what: Installation (NOTE: THE COMPATABILITY WILL BE FIXED IN THE FULL RELEASE)
title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: ⚠️ Compatibility Note: Version 0.12.0 introduces breaking changes support new formr API (v1). formr server instance yet support v1 API, install previous version (0.11.1). install latest version (v0.12.0+): install legacy version (compatible older servers):

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: use API features (fetching results, managing files), must first authenticate. can store credentials securely system’s keyring don’t type every time. Log formr.org go Account > API Settings. Create Client ID Secret.
code: library(formr)  # Store your credentials once # This saves them securely in your OS credential store formr_store_keys(   host = "https://formr.org", # or the URL of your instance   client_id = "YOUR_CLIENT_ID",    client_secret = "YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET" )  # Then, in all of your scripts, simply run: formr_api_authenticate(host = "https://formr.org")

what: You can use the API within your runs R-Code.
title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: package provides tools fetch data complex runs automatically join survey results, handle randomization (shuffles), type items.
code: # 1. Fetch results from a run # join = TRUE automatically merges multiple surveys and shuffles by session results <- formr_results("my-run-name", join = TRUE)  # 2. Get the run structure (items, choices, types) items <- formr_run_structure("my-run-name")  # 3. Post-process # This handles type conversion, reverse-scoring, and aggregation for you. cleaned_data <- formr_post_process_results("my-run-name")  # Your data is now ready for analysis! head(cleaned_data)

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: can now develop surveys runs locally (using Excel/JSON/RMarkdown) sync server. allows use Git version control.

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: Download everything—results, assets, survey items, run structure—local folder.

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: can pull project structure, make edits Excel files CSS locally, push back.
code: # Initialize/Sync local folder with server state formr_pull_project("my-run-name", dir = "my_project")  # ... Make changes to surveys/my-survey.xlsx or css/custom.css ...  # Push changes back to formr.org formr_push_project("my-run-name", dir = "my_project")

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: Control participants programmatically. Useful automated testing managing users.
code: # Create a test session formr_create_session("my-run-name", testing = TRUE)  # Find a specific session session_info <- formr_sessions("my-run-name", session_codes = "...")  # Move a user to a specific position in the run formr_session_action("my-run-name", session_codes = "...", action = "move_to_position", position = 10)

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: package contains utility functions used inside formr’s OpenCPU environment dynamic feedback logic: Logic Shorthands: time_passed(), %contains%, if_na(). Feedback Plots: qplot_on_normal(), qplot_on_bar(), feedback_chunk.
code: # Example: Check if a string contains a word "apple, banana" %contains% "apple" # TRUE  # Example: Feedback text logic feedback_chunk(0.5, c("Low", "Average", "High")) # Returns "Average"

title: formr survey framework accompanying R package
text: MIT

what: Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
title: Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
text: Computes row-wise aggregate (mean, sum) attaches metadata items included. Useful transparency codebooks.

title: Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
text: items data.frame/tibble items aggregate. fun Aggregation function (default: rowMeans). stem Optional manual stem name. NULL, auto-detects longest common prefix.

title: Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
text: numeric vector attributes scale_item_names label.

title: Aggregate variables and document construction — aggregate_and_document_scale
code: df <- data.frame(e1 = 1:5, e2 = 5:1, e3 = 1:5) scale_score <- aggregate_and_document_scale(df) attr(scale_score, "label") #> [1] "3 e items aggregated by rowMeans"

what: Convert formr run structure to data.frame — as.data.frame.formr_run_structure
title: Convert formr run structure to data.frame — as.data.frame.formr_run_structure
text: Convert formr run structure data.frame

title: Convert formr run structure to data.frame — as.data.frame.formr_run_structure
Convert formr run structure to data.frame — as.data.frame.formr_run_structure
text: x object. ... Additional arguments.

title: knit_child as is — asis_knit_child
text: slightly modifies knitr::knit_child() function different defaults. environment defaults calling environment. output receives class knit_asis, output rendered "" knitr calling inside chunk (need set results='asis' chunk option). defaults quiet = TRUE

title: knit_child as is — asis_knit_child
code: asis_knit_child(   input = NULL,   text = NULL,   ...,   quiet = TRUE,   options = NULL,   envir = parent.frame() )

title: knit_child as is — asis_knit_child
text: input specify file path , read passed knitr (avoid working directory mess) text passed knitr::knit_child() ... passed knitr::knit_child() quiet passed knitr::knit_child() options defaults NULL. envir passed knitr::knit_child()

title: knit_child as is — asis_knit_child
text: default calling environment? Typically function defaults global environment. makes sense want use knit_children context rest document. However, may also want use knit_children inside functions e.g. summarise regression using set commands (e.g. plot diagnostic graphs summary regression nicely formatted). caveats: function return top-level. way cat() loops -condition without without setting results='asis'. can however concatenate objects paste.knit_asis()

title: knit_child as is — asis_knit_child
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # an example of a wrapper function that calls asis_knit_child with an argument # ensures distinct paths for cache and figures, so that these calls can be looped in parallel regression_summary = function(model) {    child_hash = digest::digest(model)    options = list(        fig.path = paste0(knitr::opts_chunk$get("fig.path"), child_hash, "-"),         cache.path = paste0(knitr::opts_chunk$get("cache.path"), child_hash, "-"))    asis_knit_child("_regression_summary.Rmd", options = options) } } # }

what: How many surveys were expired? — expired
title: How many surveys were expired? — expired
text: Just simple check many times survey (e.g. diary) expired (.e. user missed ). defaults checking "expired" variable .

title: How many surveys were expired? — expired
How many surveys were expired? — expired
text: survey survey asking ? variable variable filled , defaults "ended"

title: How many surveys were expired? — expired
code: survey = data.frame(expired = c(NA, "2016-05-29 10:11:00", NA)) expired(survey = survey) #> [1] 1

what: Text feedback based on groups — feedback_chunk
title: Text feedback based on groups — feedback_chunk
text: pass z-standardised value (x - Mean)/SD, vector feedback text chunks, either three five elements, text chunks used order [low], low, average, high, [high] corresponding intervals [low, -2], [-2, -1], [-1, 1], [1, 2], [2, high]

title: Text feedback based on groups — feedback_chunk
Text feedback based on groups — feedback_chunk
text: normed_value z-standardised value chunks three five element long character vector containing text chunks feedback

title: Text feedback based on groups — feedback_chunk
code: feedback_chunk(normed_value = 0.7, chunks = c("You are rather introverted.", "You're approximately as extraverted as most people.","You are rather extraverted.")) #> [1] "You're approximately as extraverted as most people."

what: How many surveys were finished? — finished
title: How many surveys were finished? — finished
text: Just simple check many times survey (e.g. diary) finished. defaults checking "ended" variable .

title: How many surveys were finished? — finished
How many surveys were finished? — finished
text: survey survey asking ? variable variable filled , defaults "ended"

title: How many surveys were finished? — finished
code: survey = data.frame(ended = c("2016-05-28 10:11:00", NA, "2016-05-30 11:18:28")) finished(survey = survey) #> [1] 2

title: Authenticate with formr — formr_api_authenticate
text: Connects API. credentials provided, tries find keyring.

title: Authenticate with formr — formr_api_authenticate
code: formr_api_authenticate(   host = "https://formr.org",   client_id = NULL,   client_secret = NULL,   access_token = NULL )

title: Authenticate with formr — formr_api_authenticate
text: host API Base URL. client_id OAuth Client ID. client_secret OAuth Client Secret. access_token Direct Access Token.

title: Revoke Access Token (Logout) — formr_api_logout
text: Invalidates current access token server clears local session state.

text: Get Current API session

title: Backup a study — formr_backup_run
text: Downloads full run structure, survey items, attached files, results. Saves everything structured folder.

title: Backup a study — formr_backup_run
text: run_name Name run/study. dir Local folder save data (defaults run_name). prompt Logical. TRUE (default), asks confirmation overwriting.

title: Create a new run — formr_create_run
text: Creates one new runs server. Prints confirmation message public link .

title: Create a new run — formr_create_run
text: name character vector names new runs (must unique).

title: Create a new run — formr_create_run
text: Invisibly returns data frame containing name link created runs.

title: Create Session(s) — formr_create_session
text: Creates one sessions. codes NULL, one random session created. codes provided, tries create sessions specific codes.

title: Create Session(s) — formr_create_session
text: run_name Name run. codes Character vector codes. NULL, creates one random code. testing Logical. Mark sessions testing?

title: Create Session(s) — formr_create_session

what: Delete ALL files attached to a run — formr_delete_all_files
title: Delete ALL files attached to a run — formr_delete_all_files
text: CAUTION: permanently remove every file attached specified run. first fetches list existing files, iterates delete.

title: Delete ALL files attached to a run — formr_delete_all_files
Delete ALL files attached to a run — formr_delete_all_files
text: run_name Name run. prompt Logical. TRUE (default), function asks interactive confirmation deleting. Set FALSE automated scripts (use care).

what: check whether a character string begins with a string — %begins_with%
title: check whether a character string begins with a string — %begins_with%
text: Escapes special RegExp characters search term. way check whether search term (e.g. variable name) beginning. Just simple shorthand inexperienced R users use somewhat complex functions grepl() stringr::str_detect(). can also use \%starts_with\%.

title: check whether a character string begins with a string — %begins_with%
check whether a character string begins with a string — %begins_with%
text: haystack string search needle string search

title: check whether a character string begins with a string — %begins_with%
code: "1, 3, 4" %begins_with% "1" # TRUE #> [1] TRUE "1, 3, 4" %begins_with% 1 # unlike str_detect casts all needles as characters #> [1] TRUE "1, 3, 4" %begins_with% "." # FALSE #> [1] FALSE

what: check whether a character string contains another — %contains%
title: check whether a character string contains another — %contains%
text: Just simple shorthand inexperienced R users use somewhat complex functions grepl() stringr::str_detect() non-default arguments (e.g. fixed params).

title: check whether a character string contains another — %contains%
check whether a character string contains another — %contains%
text: haystack string search needle string search

title: check whether a character string contains another — %contains%
code: "1, 2, 3, 4, you" %contains% "you" #> [1] TRUE "1, 2, 3, 4, you" %contains% 1 # unlike str_detect casts all needles as characters #> [1] TRUE "1, 2, 3, 4, you" %contains% 343 #> [1] FALSE

what: check whether a character string contains another as a word — %contains_word%
title: check whether a character string contains another as a word — %contains_word%
text: Looks string appearing . needed e.g. checking whether replies mmc item, stored comma-separated list 1 12 contain option 1 - want get hit 11 12. works search terms containing alphanumeric characters. Just simple shorthand inexperienced R users use somewhat complex functions grepl() stringr::str_detect().

title: check whether a character string contains another as a word — %contains_word%
check whether a character string contains another as a word — %contains_word%
text: haystack string search needle string search

title: check whether a character string contains another as a word — %contains_word%
code: "1, 3, 4" %contains_word% "1" # TRUE #> [1] TRUE "1, 3, 4" %contains_word% 1 # TRUE unlike str_detect casts all needles as characters #> [1] TRUE "12, 14, 17" %contains_word% "1" # FALSE even though 12 contains 1 #> [1] FALSE

what: check whether a character string ends with a string — %ends_with%

check whether a character string ends with a string — %ends_with%
text: haystack string search needle string search

title: check whether a character string ends with a string — %ends_with%

what: This function makes sure you know what to expect when evaluating uncertain results in an if-clause. In most cases, you should not use this function, because it can lump a lot of very different cases together, but it may have some use for fool-proofing certain if-clauses on formr.org, where a field in a survey may either not exist, be missing or have a value to check. — if_na_null
title: This function makes sure you know what to expect when evaluating uncertain results in an if-clause. In most cases, you should not use this function, because it can lump a lot of very different cases together, but it may have some use for fool-proofing certain if-clauses on formr.org, where a field in a survey may either not exist, be missing or have a value to check. — if_na_null
text: function makes sure know expect evaluating uncertain results -clause. cases, use function, can lump lot different cases together, may use fool-proofing certain -clauses formr.org, field survey may either exist, missing value check.

title: This function makes sure you know what to expect when evaluating uncertain results in an if-clause. In most cases, you should not use this function, because it can lump a lot of very different cases together, but it may have some use for fool-proofing certain if-clauses on formr.org, where a field in a survey may either not exist, be missing or have a value to check. — if_na_null

This function makes sure you know what to expect when evaluating uncertain results in an if-clause. In most cases, you should not use this function, because it can lump a lot of very different cases together, but it may have some use for fool-proofing certain if-clauses on formr.org, where a field in a survey may either not exist, be missing or have a value to check. — if_na_null
text: test condition. can length 0 length 1 na returned condition missing value null passed ifelse

title: This function makes sure you know what to expect when evaluating uncertain results in an if-clause. In most cases, you should not use this function, because it can lump a lot of very different cases together, but it may have some use for fool-proofing certain if-clauses on formr.org, where a field in a survey may either not exist, be missing or have a value to check. — if_na_null
code: testdf = data.frame(test1 = 1, test2 = NA) if ( if_na_null(testdf$test1 == 1) ) { print("go on") } #> [1] "go on" if ( if_na_null(testdf$test2 == 1) ) { print("not shown") } if ( if_na_null(testdf$test3 == 1) ) { print("not shown") } tryCatch({ if ( if_na_null(testdf2$test1 == 1) ) { print("causes error") } },     error = function(e) { warning(e) })  #> Error: object 'testdf2' not found

what: custom markdown options for rmarkdown's pandoc — markdown_custom_options
title: custom markdown options for rmarkdown's pandoc — markdown_custom_options
text: custom markdown options rmarkdown's pandoc

title: custom markdown options for rmarkdown's pandoc — markdown_custom_options
code: markdown_custom_options(   add_to_format = c("+autolink_bare_uris", "+ascii_identifiers",     "+tex_math_single_backslash", "-implicit_figures"),   fragment.only = FALSE,   section_divs = TRUE,   break_on_error = FALSE,   ... )

title: custom markdown options for rmarkdown's pandoc — markdown_custom_options
text: add_to_format add arguments default specification fragment.whether get html fragment section_divs whether disable –section-divs (headings generate section including everything next --higher-level heading) break_on_error error R code execution interrupt rendering rendering continue, defaults FALSE ... arguments passed rmarkdown::html_document() Custom rmarkdown input format options based standard rmarkdown::html_document(), options can specify. Find format options pandoc documentation: http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/demo/example9/pandocs-markdown.html Pandoc's enhanced version markdown includes syntax footnotes, tables, flexible ordered lists, definition lists, fenced code blocks, superscript, subscript, strikeout, title blocks, automatic tables contents, embedded LaTeX math, citations, markdown inside HTML block elements spoken options: +escaped_line_breaks, +header_attributes, +yaml_metadata_block, +auto_identifiers, +implicit_header_references, +blank_before_blockquote, +fenced_code_blocks, +fenced_code_attributes, +line_blocks, +definition_lists, +startnum, +fancy_lists, +pipe_tables, +pandoc_title_block, +intraword_underscores, +strikeout, +superscript, +subscript, +tex_math_dollars, +raw_html, +markdown_in_html_blocks, +implicit_figures, +footnotes, +inline_notes, +citations. current default rmarkdown additions Pandoc's enhanced markdown : +autolink_bare_uris, +ascii_identifiers, +tex_math_single_backslash, -implicit_figures.

title: github_markdown for rmarkdown — markdown_github
text: Custom template github-flavoured markdown based standard rmarkdown::html_document(). Adds +pipe_tables, +raw_html, +tex_math_single_backslash, +fenced_code_blocks, +auto_identifiers, +ascii_identifiers, +backtick_code_blocks, +autolink_bare_uris, +intraword_underscores, +strikeout, +hard_line_breaks markdown_strict. number pandoc features disabled (see markdown_custom_options()), +yaml_metadata_block re-enabled, possible specify output function using YAML.

title: github_markdown for rmarkdown — markdown_github
text: fragment.whether get html fragment break_on_error error R code execution interrupt rendering rendering continue, defaults FALSE ... arguments passed rmarkdown::html_document()

title: hard line breaks — markdown_hard_line_breaks
text: Custom rmarkdown template based standard rmarkdown::html_document(), hard line breaks. add pandoc '+hard_line_breaks' argument origin format markdown.

title: hard line breaks — markdown_hard_line_breaks
text: ... arguments passed rmarkdown::html_document()

what: Plot normed values as a barchart — qplot_on_bar
title: Plot normed values as a barchart — qplot_on_bar
text: Pass data.frame z-standardised values (x - Mean)/SD, variable names, get bar chart. Getting data.frame shape probably mean using tidyr dplyr data.frame se column ymax/ymin columns, displayed top bars bars become transparent.

title: Plot normed values as a barchart — qplot_on_bar
code: qplot_on_bar(   normed_data,   ylab = "Your value",   xlab = "Trait",   title = "",   y_ticks = c("--", "-", "0", "+", "++") )

title: Plot normed values as a barchart — qplot_on_bar
text: normed_data dataset value column containing z-standardised value variable column containing labels values ylab Y-axis label, defaults "Percentage people value" xlab X-axis label, empty default, useful labeling plotted trait title Plot title y_ticks ticks labels -2,1,0,1 2 SDs around mean, default minuses, pluses average sign

title: Plot normed values as a barchart — qplot_on_bar
code: normed_data = data.frame(variable = c("Extraversion","Openness", "Agreeableness","Neuroticism","Conscientiousness"),  value = c(-3,1,-1,0.5,2)) # standardise value qplot_on_bar(normed_data, title = "Your personality")  normed_data = data.frame(variable = c("Extraversion","Openness", "Agreeableness","Neuroticism","Conscientiousness"),  value = c(-3,1,-1,0.5,2), se = c(0.2,0.3,0.2,0.25,0.4)) # standardise value qplot_on_bar(normed_data, title = "Your personality")

text: Pass z-standardised value (x - Mean)/SD, get standard normal distribution.

title: Plot a normed value on the standard normal — qplot_on_normal
code: qplot_on_normal(   normed_value,   ylab = "Percentage of other people with this value",   xlab = "",   colour = "blue",   x_ticks = c("--", "-", "0", "+", "++") )

title: Plot a normed value on the standard normal — qplot_on_normal
text: normed_value z-standardised value ylab Y-axis label, defaults "Percentage people value" xlab X-axis label, empty default, useful labeling plotted trait colour defaults blue x_ticks ticks labels -2,1,0,1 2 SDs around mean, default minuses, pluses average sign

title: Plot a normed value on the standard normal — qplot_on_normal
code: normed_value = scale(x = 20, center = 14, scale = 5) # standardise value qplot_on_normal(normed_value, xlab = "Extraversion")

title: Time-polar plot — qplot_on_polar
text: Pass data.frame z-standardised values (x - Mean)/SD, variable names, get bar chart. Getting data.frame shape probably mean using tidyr + dplyr. data.frame se column ymax/ymin columns, displayed top bars bars become transparent.

title: Time-polar plot — qplot_on_polar
text: normed_data dataset value column containing z-standardised value variable column containing labels values ylab Y-axis label, defaults "Percentage people value" title Plot title

title: Time-polar plot — qplot_on_polar
code: weekdays = c("Monday","Tuesday","Wednesday","Thursday","Friday","Saturday","Sunday") normed_data = data.frame(variable = factor(weekdays, weekdays),    value = c(0,1,0.2,0.5,1.5,2,1)) # standardise value qplot_on_polar(normed_data, title = "Your alcohol consumption across the week")  normed_data = data.frame(variable = factor(1:24,1:24),    value = 3+rnorm(24), se = rep(0.2,24)) # standardise value qplot_on_polar(normed_data, title = "Your mood around the clock")

title: Rescue lost attributes — rescue_attributes
text: Copies attributes (labels, SPSS formats) one data frame another. Useful dplyr operations strip attributes.

title: Rescue lost attributes — rescue_attributes
text: df_target data frame missing attributes. df_source reference data frame containing attributes.

title: Rescue lost attributes — rescue_attributes
text: df_target restored attributes.

title: Reverse labelled values — reverse_labelled_values
text: Reverses underlying values numeric haven::labelled() vector preserving updating value labels correctly. Useful reversing Likert scales (e.g., 1=Strongly Disagree -> 5=Strongly Agree).

title: Reverse labelled values — reverse_labelled_values
text: x numeric vector, potentially haven::labelled attributes.

title: Reverse labelled values — reverse_labelled_values
text: vector class values reversed.

title: Reverse labelled values — reverse_labelled_values
code: x <- haven::labelled(rep(1:3, each = 3), c(Bad = 1, Good = 5)) x #> <labelled<integer>[9]> #> [1] 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3 #>  #> Labels: #>  value label #>      1   Bad #>      5  Good reverse_labelled_values(x) #> <labelled<double>[9]> #> [1] 5 5 5 4 4 4 3 3 3 #>  #> Labels: #>  value label #>      1  Good #>      5   Bad

title: Send text message via Massenversand.de — text_message_massenversand
text: number texting (usually without zeroes beginning) number texting Body text message body/text id Massenversand ID pw Massenversand password time see provider API (defaults immediate sending) msgtype see provider API tarif see provider API test see provider API return_result whether return simply TRUE/FALSE success/failure whole result

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ text_message_massenversand(   To = '492222',    From = '15005000',    Body = 'Hello friend',   id = 'ID',    pw = 'Tokentokentoken')   } # }

what: checks how much time has passed relative to the user's last action — time_passed
title: checks how much time has passed relative to the user's last action — time_passed
text: checks much time passed. can choose unit. Implemented via lubridate::dseconds(), periods, .e. minute 60 seconds, hour 60 minutes, day 24 hours. Months years well-defined durations, offer anyway convenience.  Returns true false.

title: checks how much time has passed relative to the user's last action — time_passed
code: time_passed(   years = 0,   months = 0,   weeks = 0,   days = 0,   hours = 0,   minutes = 0,   seconds = 0,   time = NULL )

title: checks how much time has passed relative to the user's last action — time_passed
text: years 365 days months 30 days weeks 7 days days 24 hours hours 60 minutes minutes 60 seconds seconds argument lubridate::dseconds() time defaults .formr$last_action_time, hidden variable automatically set formr.org

title: checks how much time has passed relative to the user's last action — time_passed
